ETCalculator

Calculates adjusted evapotranspiration (hereinafter ET) from a “reference ET” number and other stuff like percent canopy cover or leaf-area index.

Created

31May2011

Authors

P Kaarakka, Rick Wayne

Public Instance Methods

adjETLAI(refET,lai) click to toggle source

Return adjusted ET from the reference ET and the leaf area index 

    # File lib/et_calculator.rb, line 47
47:   def adjETLAI(refET,lai)
48:   end
adjETPctCover(refET,pctCover) click to toggle source

Return the adjusted ET. Uses regression coefficients derived by J. Panuska from the UW Extension pub A3600. 

    # File lib/et_calculator.rb, line 12
12:   def adjETPctCover(refET,pctCover)
13:     # regression coefficients from J. Panuska in Linear_Regressions_for_A3600_Table.doc and based on Table C of UW Extension pub A3600, "Irrigation Management in Wisconsin - the Wisconsin Irrigation Scheduling Program (WISP)" 

14:     coeff = [[0,0][0.002263,0.2377],[0.002789,0.3956],[0.002368,0.5395],[0.000316,0.6684],[0.000053,0.7781],[0.001053,0.8772],[0.001947,0.9395],[0.000000,1.000]]
15:   
16:     #NOTE: coeffIndex and interpolations assume pctCover curves are all exactly 10% apart. 

17:     coeffIndex = (pctCover/10).floor
18:     case coeffIndex
19:       when 0  # Get zero %cover adjET

20:         case refET
21:           when 0..0.159
22:             adjETLow = 0.0
23:           when 0.160..0.319
24:             adjETLow = 0.010
25:           else 
26:             adjETLow = 0.020
27:         end
28:         # Get 10 %cover adjET

29:         adjETHigh = coeff[1][0] + refET*coeff[1][1]
30:         # Interpolate adjET between zero and 10 %cover

31:         adjET = adjETLow + ((pctCover/10)*(adjETHigh-adjETLow))
32: 
33:       when 1..7  # Get low end adjET

34:         adjETLow  = coeff[coeffIndex][0] + refET*coeff[coeffIndex][1]  
35:         # Get high end adjET

36:         adjETHigh = coeff[coeffIndex+1][0] + refET*coeff[coeffIndex+1][1]
37:         # Interpolate adjET between low and high %cover

38:         adjET = adjETLow + ((pctCover-(coeffIndex*10)/10)*(adjETHigh-adjETLow))
39: 
40:       else     # At 80% cover and above there is no adjustment to the refET

41:         adjET = refET
42:     end
43:     return adjET
44:   end
adj_ET(day) click to toggle source

Duck Typing at work here; “day” can be anything that responds to the methods “refET”, “lai”, and “pctCover”. So an ActiveRecord class instance with those table columns will work, or a mock object for testing, or wrapper around some other class that calls them referenceET and leafAreaIndex. This is a function returning the adjusted ET; it makes use of Ruby’s “last-executed statement” return value feature to avoid having to initialize a variable and explicitly return it 

    # File lib/et_calculator.rb, line 55
55:   def adj_ET(day)
56:     # look at LAI first; since pctCover is (???) more likely to have default values automatically calculated,

57:     # if LAI is present it means the user wants us to use it

58:     if day.lai
59:       adjETLAI(day.refET,day.lai)
60:     else
61:       adjETPctCover(day.refET,day.pctCover)
62:     end
63:   end
update_adj_et_single_day(day) click to toggle source

In addition to the four methods expected above for “day”, this one expects “day” to have a adjET=(et_value) method 

    # File lib/et_calculator.rb, line 67
67:   def update_adj_et_single_day(day)
68:     day.adjET =  ad_ET(day)
69:   end
